Birungi L. has been operating a retail grocery shop in Mbarara for the past 4 years. However, her business is hampered by inadequate capital. Therefore, L. is requesting a loan to purchase more rice and sugar and also to repair her rental units.

L. is a loving mother to 4 school-going children. Her dream is to expand her retail business into wholesale.

loans.use: Purchase more rice and sugar and also repair her rental units.

loans.name: Komlan

texts.fr: Né le 04 Novembre 1969 à Tsévié, Mr Komlan A. est vendeur de produits de premières nécessités (savons, boites de conserves et autres…). Il est père de cinq (05) enfants tous scolarisés et le poids du foyer repose sur lui seul, responsabilité qu’il n’arrive pas à supporter pleinement. Il sollicite, pour atteindre ses objectifs, un financement pour agrandir son commerce, satisfaire la demande sans cesse croissante de ses clients et palier à tous les problèmes financiers qu’il rencontre.
texts.en:
Born November 4, 1969 in Tsévié, Komlan A. sells basic necessities such as soaps, canned foods, and so on. He has five children who are all in school and he is solely responsible for supporting them. He is unable to meet all their needs. He is asking for financing to expand his business in order to attain his goals. He aims to satisfy his customers' ever-increasing requests and take care of any financial problems which may arise.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic necessities for resale.

loans.name: Banaletta

texts.en:
N. Banaletta runs a restaurant in the Lyatonde trading center. Her main menu includes local dishes and delicacies like luwombo, nakkati, matooke, yams and cassava.

To serve her increasing customer base, N. is requesting a loan to purchase more foodstuffs like rice, flour, cooking oil, and cereals. Her ambition is to have a modern fast foods restaurant. She is the loving mother of seven children, three of whom are still in school. The income from her business enables her to sustain her family.

loans.use: Purchase more foodstuffs like rice, flour, cooking oil, and cereals.

loans.name: Arise Bukaya Group

texts.en: Prossy M. is married and lives with six of her own children as well as two dependents.  As the leader of the Arise Bukaya Group in Lugazi, Prossy also manages a poultry business that cooks and sells meat and eggs.  When she has received loans in the past from organizations like Kiva, Prossy has invested in her business by purchasing more chicks and chicken feed.  It is her hope that surplus income can be set aside to pay for her children's school fees.  She is now requesting a loan of $3,350 to further develop her business.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Née en 1970 Tsévié, Mme Akouvi F. est une grande commerçante de pagnes depuis plus de huit (08) ans. Douée et expérimentée dans ce commerce qu’elle exerce avec ses propres moyens financiers dont les revenus tirés n’arrivent pas à couvrir ses charges, Mme Akouvi sollicite un crédit pour augmenter son étalage de pagnes afin de pouvoir satisfaire tous ses clients et accroître considérablement son chiffres d’affaires et ses bénéfices.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Tsévié, Madam Akouvi F. has been a major merchant of "pagnes" (colorful West African cloth) for over eight years. Talented and experienced as she is, doing commerce in this field using her own funds, she has not been able to derive the revenues to support her family. And so she is requesting this loan to expand her display of pagnes in order to satisfy all her customers and to grow her sales figures and profits considerably.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in pagnes

loans.name: Prudence

texts.en: M. Prudence sells clothes and decorative accessories in Mbarara. Due to increased customer demand, she is requesting a loan to replenish her stock of fabrics to meet the tastes and preferences of her customers. Her dream is to open up an upscale boutique within the district. She is married with two children who both attend secondary school.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics

loans.name: Better

texts.fr: Agée de 33 ans, Mme Better K. est mariée et mère de six (06) enfants. Son mari est sans emploi, ce qui oblige Mme Better à faire face seule aux charges de la famille. Spécialisée dans la préparation de l’huile de palme, elle éprouve d’énormes difficultés car le travail se fait manuellement. Dotée d’une bonne moralité, elle sollicite un financement pour augmenter le volume de sa production, seul moyen d’accroître ses revenus et rendre sa famille heureuse.
texts.en:
Madam Better K. is 33 years old, married, and the mother of six. Her husband is unemployed, which compels her to cope with family expenses. A specialist in making palm oil, she is experiencing enormous difficulties because the work is done manually. A woman of good character, she is requesting financing to increase her production volume. This is the only means of increasing her income and bringing happiness to her family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Making and selling palm oil

loans.name: Konul

texts.en: Konul Q. is a 20-year-old woman who has been breeding sheep for the last three years. She is married and has a child. Sheep-breeding is the only source of income for Konul and her husband. Konul looks after the sheep and her husband pastures them and sells them in the livestock bazaar. They have divided their chores equally and they really enjoy their everyday work. Konul's dream is to become an entrepreneur with a big farm consisting of 100-200 sheep.  She believes such a business will provide her child a better life and the opportunity for a good education. She has applied for this loan to purchase nine sheep and fodder. Your generosity can help her approach her dream.

loans.use: Purchase nine sheep and fodder

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more timber in bulk

loans.name: Georgette

texts.fr: Née en 1970, Mme D. Georgette est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle est couturière de métier et exerce actuellement à Gapé. Courageuse et honnête, elle emploie cinq (05) apprenties couturières, ce qui engendre un manque cruel de matériels de travail, notamment les machines à coudre. Pour mettre à la disposition de tous ses apprenties le matériel de travail indispensable, elle sollicite un financement pour acheter de nouvelles machines à coudre. Cela va lui permettre de répondre satisfaire rapidement ses clients et d’accroître ses revenus.
texts.en:
Born in 1970, Madam Georgette D. is married and a mother with one child. She is a dressmaker by trade and currently works in Gapé. A courageous and honest woman, she employs five apprentice dressmakers, and so there is a terrible lack of supplies and equipment, notably sewing machines. To provide what is indispensible to the work of her apprentices, she is requesting financing to buy new sewing machines. This will enable her to satisfy her customers quickly and to grow her revenues.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing machines for her workshop

loans.name: Dembe Group1

texts.en: Robinah N. is the leader of the Dembe women’s group that has been in existence for 5 years.  She is a married woman with two kids and manages two businesses.  She is a farmer growing mostly bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes, as well as making local alcohol to sell to bars around her home and in town centers.  With the local brew, she makes waragi and tonto.  In a week, Robinah can make and sell eight jerry cans of tonto and seven of waragi for wholesale, as well as selling to her customers that drink from her homestead.  Robinah needs a loan to buy more bananas and pay employees for working in her farming business.

loans.use: Buying more bananas and paying employees

loans.name: Groupement

texts.fr: Le groupement  V. est un groupe familial composé de Monsieur AZIADRO Kokou Domefa né à Tsévié et âgé de 37 ans et Madame ALITE Akouvi,  32 ans née également à Tsévié. Cette famille très dynamique, a entrepris très tôt L. fabrication de savon sauvage appelé communément  « KPEVIDI ». Ce savon est fabriqué à base d’huile rouge et soude caustique et autres ingrédients qui, aussitôt préparé, trouve de preneurs à l’intérieur du pays. Cette famille dispose des moyens très insuffisants pour satisfaire sa clientèle malgré l’appui financier de tout coté. Actuellement elle sollicite un crédit pour l’achat de produits de fabrication. Une fois ce crédit accordé, cette famille honnête et laborieuse pourra améliorer ses conditions de vie socio-économique.
texts.en:
The "V." [Victory] group is a family group made up of Mr. Kokou Domefa Aziadro, born in Tsévié and 37 years of age, and Mrs. Akouvi Alite, 32 years old and also born in Tsévié. This is a very energetic family who started early on making soap known as "KPEVIDI". This soap made from red palm oil and caustic soda and other ingredients. As quickly as they make the soap, it is bought by customers in the interior of the country. This family is not in a position to meet their customers' demand despite financial help from all sides. They are now asking for a loan to purchase the raw materials to make more soap. Once the loan is extended, this honest and hard-working family will be able to improve their living conditions.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make and sell soap.

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy P., 58, and her husband, Mr. Sok Men, 66, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.  They have been married for 16 years and have two daughters.  One of their children is a garment factory worker and the other one attends school.

Sophy is a housewife and takes care of her children.  Sok has been a pedicab driver for ten years.  He drives in Phnom Penh and has revenue of about $3 a day.  Sophy is requesting a loan for $500 to dig a well to use for the family and to purchase a cow for raising.

loans.use: To dig a well to use for the family and to purchase a cow for raising.

loans.name: Robinah's Group

texts.en: Robinah N. is a mother of four children and the leader of her group.  She has a retail shop selling soda, juice and mineral water in Namawojjolo's trading center.  She also sells chickens to the same customers.  Her previous loans have helped her buy more chicken, sodas, water and juice to sell, and as a result, the profits have enabled her to look after her family and pay school fees for her children.  She plans on starting a poultry business in order to reap profits as her own supplier. Robinah is in need of another loan to help restock her shop with more soda, mineral water, juice and buying more chicken for roasting.

loans.use: More chicken, soda and other cold drinks to sell

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Savoeun V., 32, and his wife, Mrs. Rany Som, 22, were married in 2004 and have no children.  The family lives in a small village along National Road #5 about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Savoeun has been a driver for a garment factory for three years.  He also rents his own car to the garment factory to carry goods.  His wife has been selling clothes for two years.  She buys them from the Olympic market, located in Phnom Penh, and resells them in front of the garment factory. 

Savoeun is requesting a loan for $1000 to build a fence around his house.

loans.use: To build fence of his house.

loans.name: Mercy B.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Mercy K. from Mbeya. She is married with one child who is four years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans whose parents died of AIDS. Mercy has been running a tailoring business since 2006.

She works at the business for 13-16 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by two employees. Mercy currently earns about 210 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 550 USD in order to purchase threads for making clothes. In the future, she plans to start making other types of clothes. Mercy thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase threads for making clothing

loans.name: Bunthorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Bunthorn C., 59, and her husband, Mr. Hey Hun, 62, live in a small village along National Road #5, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.  They were married in 1982 and have ten children: four sons and six daughters.  Three of them are married and live outside the family house.  Two daughters are garment factory workers, one son is a fisherman and the other children attend school.  

Bunthorn has been a fish farmer for 2 years.  It is a skill she learned from her neighbor.  She buys small fishes to raise; when the fishes grow enough, she sells them to a middleman.  Her husband has been a fisherman for 15 years.  He fishes in the river nearby his house.  

Bunthorn is requesting a loan of $1000 to buy a surface air supply system to dive into the river to place fishing nets. Parts of a surface air supply system include a generator, air compressor, regulators, and diving harnesses.  The remainder of the loan will be used to fishing nets.

loans.use: To buy a surface air supply system for diving in the river and fishing nets.

loans.name: Apédo

texts.fr: Mr A. Apédo est né en 1968 à Gapé-Centre. Marié et père de cinq (05) enfants, il a cessé les études et se lance très tôt dans de petites activités génératrices de revenus en achetant un meule pour aiguiser les houes et les coupe-coupe de ses frères agriculteurs dans la localité moyennant quelques sous insignifiants. Manquant de moyens, il n’arrive pas à développer son activité, ce qui le pousse à solliciter un crédit pour acheter une nouvelle machine. Actif et honnête, il tient toujours à ses promesses. Cette machine une fois achetée lui permettra d’avoir un rendement meilleur et d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Apédo A. was born in 1968 in Gapé-Centre. He is married and has five children. He left school early and began working at small income-generating jobs, buying a grindstone to sharpen the hoes and machetes of the neighbouring farmers, making only a pittance. Because of a lack of money, he is unable to expand his business which is why he is asking for a loan to buy a new grinding machine. He is active and honest and always keeps his promises. Once he buys the new machine, he will be more productive and be able to improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a grindstone

loans.name: At

texts.en:
Mrs. At C., 39, and her husband, Mr. Bros Sun, 45, live in a small village across Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.  They were married in 1983 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. One child is married, two children are fish sellers, one child is a silk weaver, and the other children assist their parents in farming. 

At has been a silk weaver for ten years.  She sells her finished products to a middleman that then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.  Her husband has been a farmer for twenty years.  He grows sugar cane and other farm crops.  At is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase silk material for weaving; also, part of the loan will be used to grow sugar cane and buy smoked fish for resale.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving, sugar cane for growing and smoked fish for resale.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Miss. Phalla P., age 26, is single and lives with her father and her sisters who are a garment factory workers. The family lives in a small village across Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Phalla has been a silk weaver for five years. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Phalla is requesting a loan of 550 to purchase silk material for her weaving business and to buy rice for food.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving and to buy rice for food.

loans.name: Georgette

texts.fr: Agée de 37 ans, Mme F. Georgette est mariée et mère de trois (03) enfants. Actuellement divorcée, son ex mari ne participe pas aux charges de ses enfants, et tout le poids de la famille se repose sur elle seule. Pour surmonter ses difficultés, elle a bénéficié un petit crédit qui lui a permis d’ouvrir un petit restaurant dans son village. Actuellement, elle sollicite un crédit pour réaménager son petit restaurant et s’approvisionner en denrées alimentaires. Ceci lui permettra de mieux satisfaire ses clients et de dégager une marge bénéficiaire élevée susceptibles d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Georgette F. is 37 years old, was married, and has three children. Now divorced, her ex-husband does not support his children: she alone is responsible for the family. To overcome her difficulties, she borrowed a small amount with which she opened a little restaurant in her village. She is now asking for a loan to reorganize her little restaurant and to buy food supplies. She will then be able to better satisfy her customers and make a greater profit, thus improving her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To organize her restaurant and buy food supplies.

loans.name: Chaileang

texts.en:
Mrs. Chaileang, 41, is widowed with three children: two sons and one daughter. All of her children are currently in school. Their family lives on an Island on Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 
Chaileang has been a silk weaver for twenty one years. She learned her trade from her sister. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $200 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.name: Scola B.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Scola M. from Tukuyu. She is married with two children aged five and nine. Scola has been running a genge business since 2005. The Swahili word for a small outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Scola currently earns about 300 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375 USD in order to purchase more rice, maize flour, beans, cooking oil and sugar in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of items she carries. Scola thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, maize flour, beans, cooking oil and sugar in bulk

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr: Monsieur L. Koffi, né le 02 Mars 1968 à Gamé Kové au Sud du Togo, est père de huit (08) enfants. Il a abandonné ses études et s’est adonné au métier de meunier. Seul meunier dans sa localité,  il ne dispose que d’un seul moulin qui tombe fréquemment en panne et dont les frais de réparation consomme toutes les économies réalisées. Il veut procéder au renouvellement de son moulin et sollicite à cette fin un financement qui va lui permettre de satisfaire ses clients et d’accroître ses revenus.
texts.en:
Koffi L. was born on March 2, 1968 in Gamé Kové in the South of Togo. He has eight children. He left school and became a miller. He is the only miller in his area and has only one mill which often breaks down. Fixing the mill uses up all of his savings. He wants to buy a new mill and is therefore asking for a loan to this end, which will allow him to offer better service to his customers and increase his revenues.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy, install and put a new mill to use.

loans.name: Ester J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Ester M. from Tukuyu. She is married with three children between the ages of 6 and 11. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because her parents cannot take care of her. 

Ester has been running a business selling crops since 1997. Her business is to purchase maize, beans, rice and wheat from villages and sell them in town at higher price. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Ester currently earns about 300USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more maize, rice, wheat and beans in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Ester thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more maize, rice, wheat and beans in bulk

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Née en 1969 à Tsévié dans la préfecture du Zio, Mme Afi B. est revendeuse de médicaments génériques et de pommades dans le village de Gapé Centre. Elle est mère de sept (07) enfants. Elle a entrepris la vente de médicaments génériques avec peu de moyens financiers. Elle sollicite un crédit pour ouvrir une petite pharmacie dans le village afin de mieux protéger ses produits et s’approvisionner suffisamment en médicaments auprès de la CAMEG (Centrale d’Achat des Médicaments Essentiels et Génériques). Ce financement va lui permettre de répondre aux besoins en médicaments des populations et d’augmenter ses bénéfices.
texts.en:
Mrs. Afi B. was born in 1969 in Tsévié in the prefecture of Zio. She is a retailer of generic medicines and ointments in the village of Gapé Centre. She is the mother of seven children. She started selling generic medicines with very little financial means. She is requesting a loan to open a small pharmacy in the village.This will allow her to better protect her products, and to stock up on enough medicines at the CAMEG (Central Purchasing Agency of Basic and Generic Medicines). This financing will allow her to meet the population's needs in medicines, and increase her profit.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Retail of basic and generic medicines

loans.name: Osioda A -1 Group

texts.en:
T. Angella (front row, center) is the representative of the Osioda A-1 group. She is 29 years old and sells secondhand clothes in the Kumi market. She sources her stock from the neighboring Mbale market. Her profit margin is 30-50%. Because 80% of her clients are ladies, T. is requesting a loan to replenish her stock of skirts, blouses, and dresses.

T. is hardworking and cooperative. She is married with two children, aged 3 and 5 years. Her dream is to open a trendy unisex boutique so that she can increase her income and enable her children to attend institutions of higher learning.

The other members of T.’s group are actively involved in various business activities such as selling fish, snacks, vegetables and milk, as well as local brewing.

loans.use: Purchase skirts, blouses, and dresses.

loans.name: Naomi K.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 31-year-old Naomi D. from Mbeya. She is married with two children aged two and four. Naomi has been running a genge business since 1997. The Swahili word for a small outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Naomi currently earns about 30 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375 USD in order to purchase more onions, tomatoes, rice and fish in bulk. Naomi thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more onions, tomatoes, rice and fish in bulk

loans.name: Hadija C.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Hadija M. from Tukuyu. She is married with two children aged four and seven. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because their parents cannot take care of them. Hadija has been running a timber business since 2006. Hadija's business is purchasing timber from villages and selling in town for a higher price.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her mother and young brother. Hadija currently earns about 200 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375 USD in order to purchase more timber in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Hadija thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more timber in bulk

loans.name: Carol's Group

texts.en: Carol N. is a very friendly person who owns a beauty salon called Mama Emmanuel's. She is a 34 year old mother and wife of 5 children. In her salon, she does braiding, weaving, shampooing and setting, retouching and all kinds of treatments with a plan to enlarge her salon's offerings to include facials. She works hard to ensure that her children attain the best of education by ensuring that her salon continues to grow. Carol plans to use her loan to buy more braids, weaves, shampoos and chemicals for her business.

loans.use: Buying beauty supplies to expand her business

loans.name: Osioda A - 2 Group

texts.en:
A. Sarah (front, far right) represents the Osioda A-2 group. She is very hardworking and social. She is 28 years of age and sells clothes, shoes, bags, suitcases and other items. She travels to Kampala twice a month to purchase her stock, and has been in business for 3 years. This loan will enable Sarah to purchase trendy products for her customers, including dresses, suitcases, shoes and bags.

Sarah is a widow with two children who are both in school. Her ambition is to open a shop outlet in the neighboring town. She also hopes to build a house for her family.The other members of Sarah’s group are involved in various business activities like selling cereals, clothes, and fish.

loans.use: Purchase dresses, suitcases, shoes and bags.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary M. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  Mary is 30 years old and her husband is a finance officer. She has five children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation. BRAC encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Edirisa's Group

texts.en: B. Edirisa is a member of Victoria women’s group in Lugazi. He is a married man with a hardworking wife and 5 children, all of which are in school. Edirisa runs a retail shop from which he sells sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, eggs and much more. The secret behind his success is making sure that his shop is well stocked into a one stop shop. He is proud that he is no longer renting and has attained more household items and a plot of land that he will use to build commercial houses. He needs another loan to help with restocking his shop to bring in more income.

loans.use: More sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, eggs and so much more for shop expansion.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en: Julia K. sells electronics at the shop and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Julia is 27 years old and is divorced. She has four children who are currently in school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. It encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which targets returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: school fees for children

loans.name: Osioda B -3 Group

texts.en:
Margret M. (back row, far right) is a hardworking business woman who is 35 years old. For two years now, she has been selling smoked fish in Kumi and various neighboring markets. Her profit margin lies at approximately 35% of sales. The loan proceeds will enable M. to purchase more sacks of dried tilapia fish.

M. is married and the mother of four school-going children. Her dream is to sell clothes so her children can go through school successfully. The other members of her group have businesses selling snacks, fruits and vegetables, cereals, and clothes.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of dried tilapia fish.

loans.name: Reala

texts.en: Reala A. is currently in the business of selling tea at the resturant and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  Reala is 27 years old and is maried to a man that is a nurse.   She has 2 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: expand her business

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en: Mary M. is 37 years old and married with 7 children, but she also cares for 5 orphans. She is a farmer, but also sells second hand clothes from the daily markets around Lugazi and Jinja. She descends to her farm very early in the morning, and in the afternoons she goes to the markets to sell her clothes; leaving her children and other helpers to finish with the farm work. She now has four cows and five goats plus other commodities that she has attained through her work. Even her clothes are now of higher qualities and are easier to be sold.

loans.use: More clothing for her stock plus paying labor on her farm using the loan.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en: Teresa is currently in the business of selling tea at a local restaurant.  Teresa is thirty-seven years old, married, and has 5 children who all go to school.  With the loan she will expand her business and with the profit she will support her family.  She will also approach poverty issues with the additional profit.

loans.use: expand business; pay children's tuition

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en: Vicky K. is currently in the business of selling onions, tomatoes and other products at a market. She is requesting a loan to expand her business. Vicky is 26 years old and a widow. She has 2 children who go to school, and with the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business and continue her children's education.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Frisita's Group

texts.en: Frisita N. is the leader of the Victoria group, very hard working, and involved in the bar business. She makes the local brew herself with bananas and sells them both in retail to home customers as well as selling to other bar owners that are not able to make the brew themselves. She makes tonto and waragi, both delicacies of the local communities mostly enjoyed in the evenings after a hard day’s work. This is Frisita’s 34th loan and all of them have been helping her in her business as well as being able to buy other beers like Bell lager, Nile Beer and others made in big factories for increased income. She is also a farmer with matooke, cassava, and sweet potato plantains for home consumption and the excess is sold to cater for home needs.  She is married with children, some of whom are out of school, but care for 3 grand children. Frisita needs a loan to be able to buy more bananas, sorghum, and buying grass for making her brew.

loans.use: More bananas, sorghum and buying grass for making her local brew.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria currently bakes and sells bread for a living and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Victoria is a widowed 27 years. She has 2 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business. She wishes to pay for her children’s education with the profits from her newly enhanced business.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine E. is currently in the business of selling tea and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Josephine is 36 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 2 children that go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business. She is a member of BRAC, whose approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs in terms of its scale and diversity of projects.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. Its microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: expanding her tea business and investing in the future of her family and business

loans.name: Rehema's Group

texts.en: K. Rehema is the leader of Tusitukire wamu group in Lugazi. She is 40 years old with a business of selling new clothes including ladies wear, children's skirts, dresses, knickers and T-shirts for 11 years. She is married with 6 children between the age of 22 and 8 years and she cares for one orphan aged 15 years. Ever since Rehema joined her lending group, now in her 35th cycle, she has managed to buy herself a plot of land. She has maintained the growth of her business as well as continuing to pay school fees for her children; the eldest being in Senior year of high school, and if all goes well, she will be able to attend the University. Rehema now needs another loan to help with buying more new clothes for her business to sell.

loans.use: More new clothes to be bought from Kampala shops for sell in her stock.

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis M. is currently in the business of selling soft drinks at the market and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Luis is 45 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the money from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Expanding soft-drink selling business.

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Getrude Wisso from Dar es Salaam She is married. She is also responsible for supporting two dependents because their parents can not take care of them. Getrude has been running a pharmacy since 2005. Her business is doing well. She works at the business for 14 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her husband and one employee. Getrude currently earns about 300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 225 USD in order to purchase additional medicine. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of her medicines. Getrude thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional medicine

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane K. is currently in the business of selling carcoals and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  Jane is 45 years old and is Widowed. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. BRAC encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Josephine D. from Dar es Salaam. She is widowed with two children between the ages of 4 and 6 years. Josephine has been running a clothes selling business since 2005. Her business is to buy clothes wholesale and sell them on a retail basis.  She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Josephine currently earns about 400 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 750 USD in order to purchase additional stock of clothes. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Josephine thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of clothes.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 58-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Ali has been selling CDs and electrical appliances for 39 years. Ali requested a loan of 1200 US dollars from Al Majmoua (Kiva's Field Partner) in order to purchase CDs, MP3s and electronics. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. 

Ali's business stands out because he has low prices. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. He decided on doing this business to take care of household needs. In the future, he plans to improve his work.

loans.use: To purchase CDs, MP3s and electrical appliances.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en: Lawrence K. lives with his wife in Lugazi. He is the proud father of seven children (six of whom are in school) and a caring brother of his two sisters. Mr. K. is a hard working and industrious entrepreneur with multiple ventures. He owns a store that sells fish, mukene, and chicken mash and he owns and operates a theater that shows translated films. His fish business mostly supplies to local Kampala customers. Lawerence employs two people: one in his fish store and one in his theater. Lawrence manages all of his other businesses himself. He is requesting a loan to purchase supplies to produce more of his famous chicken mash, as well as expanding the food in his retail inventory.

loans.use: purchasing supplies to expand food sale business

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 26-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Mahmoud has been a barber for seven years. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua (Kiva's Field Partner) in order to purchase a barber's chair. This is the first time that Mahmoud has requested a loan.

Mahmoud hopes that the loan will help him increase his income. He is special in his work because he is the only barber in his village and he knows about modern haircuts. His clients are men and teenagers of the village.

loans.use: To purchase a barber's chair.

loans.name: Marry

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Marry M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children between the ages of 8 and 17 years. Additionally, Marry is responsible of supporting one child because he is an orphan. Marry has been running a bar business since 1998. Her bar is a good place to relax with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. You can relax on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to everyone who happens to wander by.

She works at her business for 14-16 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Marry currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 225 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of beer, soda and other drinks. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Marry thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer, soda and other drinks.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Helen M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with one child who is 16 years old. Helen has been running a grocery business since 2000. She owns a small duka or neighborhood shop in the city where she sells common household and grocery items. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Helen currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 225 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, sugar, cooking oil, and soda. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Helen thanks you for your support. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of rice, sugar, cooking oil, and soda.

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en: Sarah B. is the leader of Kisimba group in Lugazi. She is a business woman with a bar and a restaurant that she has been managing from her home for a long time. In all her businesses, she employs 2 people that help her out and so far, business is not bad; and as a result, she has been able to buy her self a plot of land, build a house, buy house hold items as well as pay school fees for her children each term. Sarah needs another loan to help with buying necessary food and supplies for her restaurant and wines, beer, and local brews for her bar.

loans.use: Buying food supplies like matooke, rice, beans, cassava and more for her restaurant plus buying wines, beers and local brew for her bar.

loans.name: La Luz Group

texts.en: Lionel B. is the group leader of an organization consisting mostly of women. This group is located in La Romana, found in the south-western Dominican Republic. He is a 45-year-old father of two children. One of the biggest challenges he's yet to face has been starting his own business, and keeping it profitable in order to provide for his family. With this new loan, he expects to buy new merchandise so his clients will have a wider variety of options to choose from. He hopes loans like this will help his business grow so he can eventually have a house of his own. Thank you for supporting this loan!

loans.use: Expanding inventory

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en: Mambo from Tanzania! This is 48-year-old Mwanaidi M. from Dar es Salaam. She is a divorced women with two children between the ages of 7 and 15. Mwanaidi has been running a cafe business since 2004. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Mwanaidi currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 525 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, sugar, cooking oil, and soda. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Mwanaidi thanks you for your support. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of rice, sugar, cooking oil, and soda.

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en: Margaret W. is the proud owner of a retail shop in Kisimba. She is 38 years old and married with 4 children. In her retail shop, Margaret has been able to retain her customers and attract more by stocking her shop with products that appeal to everyone. She sells sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, maize flour and many other things that are a necessity in a village. Margaret needs a loan to be able to buy more products so as to expand her business and make more profit.

loans.use: More shop products for shop expansion.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is year 48-year-old Asia D. from Dar es Salaam. She is widowed with five children between the ages of 17 and 27 years. Asia has been running an animal feed business since 2004. Her business is to sell chicken, cow and pig feed.  She works at the business for 14 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Asia currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 225 USD in order to purchase additional stock of animal feed.  In the future, she plans to expand her business. Asia thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of animal feed.

loans.name: Barbara's Group

texts.en:
Barbara S., 43, is the leader of Kisimba Group in Lugazi. She is a single mother of 5 and she cares for 3 orphans wholeheartedly. Barbara has three businesses; she sells green bananas, both in bunches and in heaps, and she sells fuel from a pump (mostly paraffin and petrol) as well as having a restaurant where she prepares local dishes for her customers in Kisimba.

Recently, she also opened up an outlet where she sells hairpieces and hair products which is so far doing well. From her savings, Barbara has been able to buy a plot of land. She owns three cows and freely pays her children’s school fees. She is very grateful for the loans from Pearl Microfinance.

loans.use: Mostly buying foodstuffs for her restaurant, but also fuel and green bananas for her businesses

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 50-year-old Ester N. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children between the ages of 20 and 31 years. Ester has been running a poultry (kuku) business since 2005. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.  She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Ester currently earns about 250 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 375 USD in order to purchase additional chicks and feed. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Ester thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks and feed.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Anna S. from Dar es Salaam. She is widowed with one child who is 14 years old. Anna has been running a tailoring equipment business since 2002. Her business is to sell tailoring equipment to people conducting tailoring business.  She works at the business for 10 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Anna currently earns about 400 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 525 USD in order to purchase additional stock of equipment. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Anna thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loans.use: To purchase additional stock of tailoring equipment.

loans.name: Elinaike

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 48-year-old Elinaike K. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with five children between the ages of 12 and 24 years. Elinaike has been running a beauty salon business since 1998. This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own. She works at the business for 10 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Elinaike currently earns about 120 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 225 USD in order to purchase additional hair products. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Elinaike thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. loans.use: To purchase additional hair products for her salon.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en: Mwanaisha A. is a micro-businesswoman; she runs a business selling both fresh and fried fish at Vituka ward. Fish is highly consumed in Dar es Salaam. She purchases from Dar es Salaam fish market at FERRY FISH MARKET and sells to customers in Vituka. So many women in Dar es Salaam are engaged in this business. A lot of income is derived from this business. She has been in the business for seven years. She pays the school fees for her children and meets their daily demands. She is in need of T.shs 800,000 to boost her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Isack

texts.en: Isack S. is a Tanzanian businessman. He runs a clothing and shoe shop at Kilakala Yombo Vituka in Dar es Salaam. He has been in the business for four years. He buys his inventory items from the wholesale shops in Kariakoo business center. Supplying his family's daily needs depends directly on his business income. The business demand is very high compared to his capacity to supply the goods. He is requesting a loan of T. shs 600,000 to buy more items.

loans.use: to buy more business inventory

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 44-year-old Hadija L. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with five children between the ages of 9 and 24 years. Hedija has been running a soft drinks business since 2000. It is a good business in Dar es Salaam because the city is hot, therefore people must take cold drinks frequently to cool their bodies. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 5 days per week and is assisted by two employees. Hadija currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 225 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of soft drinks such as soda and drinking water. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Hadija thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of soft drinks and drinking water.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 41-year-old Asha Y. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children between the ages of 12 and 22 years old. Asha has been running a bun making and selling business since 2006. Buns are a delicious food and many people like them. People eat them with tea or juice during breakfast time. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Asha currently earns about 300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 525 USD in order to purchase wheat flour and cooking oil.  In the future, she plans to open a store. Asha thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Mambo from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Diana M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with one child who is three years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependants who depend on her because they are orphans. Diana has been running a cafe business since 2005. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savory banana) all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Asha currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 525 USD in order to purchase wheat and maize flour, cooking oil, and rice. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Diana thanks you for your support. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase wheat and maize flour, cooking oil, and rice.

loans.name: Nancy Magaly

texts.es:
Nancy Magali es socia del Banco Comunal Suni.
Nancy es conviviente, tiene 34 años y 2 hijos, Nancy vende golosinas, tarjetas y lubricantes en un grifo ubicado en la vía Libertadores en donde trabaja su esposo. Además Nancy vende productos naturales por catálogos.
Nancy necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de lubricantes y golosinas.
Nancy sueña con tener una granja de cuyes, gallinas en la ciudad de Ayacucho, tener un restaurante y que sus hijos culminen sus estudios.
texts.en:
Nanci Magali is a member of the Suni Village Bank. She 34, and has a live-in partner and 2 children. She sells candy, phone cards, and auto lubricants at a gas station located on Vía Libertadores. Her partner works there, too. She also sells natural products through catalogs. Nancy needs a loan of 3000 soles, which she will invest in candy and lubricants. Her dreams include having a guinea pig and chicken farm in the city of Ayacucho, having a restaurant, and helping her children complete their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase auto lubricants and candy.

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is a married mom with one daughter. She lives in Kherson and sells domestic electrical appliances in Dneprovskyi market. Ludmila has her vending location in a very favorable spot which is always busy with customers. She has been running this business for 15 years. Presently, Ludmila has 40,000 Grivnas invested in her business. Her income is 5,000 Grivnas a month.

Ludmila knows how to run her business. She has analytical thinking and can quickly generate solutions in the most challenging situations. Moreover, Ludmila adjusts well to all innovations and uses them to benefit her business. This time Ludmila is requesting a loan of 5,000 Grivnas to increase her inventory. She is hoping to repay the current loan in 8 months.

loans.use: increase inventory

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
Berta es socia del Banco Comunal Suni.
Berta es madre soltera, tiene 30 años y 1 hijo, Berta tiene una tienda en su casa ubicada en la selva de Palmapampa que se ubica a 7 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho, en donde vende pantalones, polos, ropa de bebe, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Lima.
Berta necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa de bebe.
Los sueños de Berta son construir el segundo piso de su casa, surtir con mas productos su tienda.
texts.en:
Berta is a member of the Community Bank “Suni”. Berta is a single mother. She is 30 years old and she has a son. She lives in the Palmapampa forest, 7 hours away from the city of Ayacucho, where she sells pants, sweaters, baby clothes, and others. She purchases all her products in the city of Lima. Berta needs a loan of 1000 soles ($325), which she will use to purchase baby clothes. Berta’s dream is to build a second floor in her house and to diversify her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase baby clothes

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 21-year-old Zaituni O. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children between the ages of 5 and 7 years old. Zaituni has been running a taloring business since 2006. Her business is to make clothes and for her customers. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 5 days per week. Zaituni currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 450 USD in order to purchase cloth for making dresses and other materials for making clothes.  In the future, she plans to expand her business.  Zaituni thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cloth for making dresses and other materials for making clothes.

loans.name: Konstantin

texts.en:
Konstantin is divorced. He lives in Kherson, in the southern part of Ukraine. Konstantin sells bikes and accessories in the local Dneprovskyi market. He offers a good assortment of inventory and the quality of all his stock is always the best. Konstantin has been in this business for 6 years. He has about 21,000 Grivnas invested in his business. His monthly income is about 5,000 Grivnas.

Konstantin is very disciplined, responsible, and accurate in every activity he takes on. He likes healthy competition but would never envy the success of his fellow businessmen who work in the same sphere of business. His competitors talk about him as a competent, respectful, and balanced entrepreneur. Konstantin is seeking a 5,000 Grivna loan to purchase additional merchandise for his vending kiosk, expecting to increase his income as a result.

loans.use: purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Norah M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children between the ages of 2 and 4 years old. Norah has been running a beauty salon business since 2006. This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Norah currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 600 USD in order to purchase hair products and a dryer. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Norah thanks you for her support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase hair products and hair dryer.

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya has two grown daughters. They live in Belaya Tserkov. Nataliya is a small market entrepreneur and sells women’s clothing and footwear in a marketplace located in Levanevskogo district of her home town. Nataliya has been in this business for 10 years. She has already invested about 30,000 Grivnas in this business.

Nataliya is hoping to use the loan of 5,000 Grivnas to increase assorted inventory for sale in her kiosk which would help her increase her proceeds and net profit as a result. She is planning to invest a portion of the income generated from the sales into completion of reconstruction project of her apartment.

Nataliya is very hard-working. She is a true fighter – she never gives up and keeps moving on no matter what. Nataliya is willing to take on financial burdens of her family and her daughters’, too, and wants to make sure they have all they need.

loans.use: purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
Felicitas es socia del Banco Comunal Suni.
Felicitas es soltera, tiene 42 años y vive con su madre, Felicitas se dedica a la siembra de verduras en sus terrenos de la comunidad de Chacco, y también compra verduras de los productores de su zona, para luego transportarlos a la ciudad de Ayacucho y comercializarlos en el mercado de abastos.
Felicitas necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de verduras, semilla y abono.
Los sueños de Felicitas son mejorar su negocio, producir mas verduras.
texts.en:
Felicitas is a member of the Suni Community Bank (Suni means 'high' in Quechua, and is one of the eight Natural Regions of Peru). She is single, 42 years old, and lives with her mother. Felicitas works growing vegetables in her fields in the community of Chacco, and also buys vegetables from local farmers to take to the city of Ayacucho and sell in the wholesale food market. Felicitas needs a loan of 1,000 soles to buy vegetables, seeds and fertilizer. She hopes to improve her business and produce more vegetables.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is single. She is an entrepreneur from Bolekhiv. Olga sells groceries in one of the local markets. She started this business with the help of her friend four years ago. She has gained a good clientele since she started working. Currently, she already has about 4,000 Grivnas in gross income. Her inventory amounts to 25,000 Grivnas.

Olga is requesting 5000 Grivnas as a loan to purchase fruit, fish, and other products for her small kiosk. She is hoping to see her business expand and grow consistently. Olga has a cheerful personality which is always a positive factor in work with customers. She is willing to work really hard to see her business flourish in the future.

loans.use: purchase food inventory

loans.name: Lucky

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 25 year old Lucky J. M. from Dar es Salaam. She is single. She is responsible for supporting two dependants because they are schooling in he area.  Lucky has been running a clothing business since 2007. She buys clothes wholesale and sell them retail. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Lucky currently earns about 420 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 750 USD in order to purchase additional stock of clothing. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Lucky thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of clothing.

loans.name: Pavlo

texts.en:
Pavlo is married and has a one-year-old daughter. Their family lives in Drogobych. Pavlo runs a small business offering vehicle refurbishment services and further sales of used cars. His business is located in one of the local car markets. Pavlo works with his brother who drives used cars from England and then leaves them at Pavlo’s shop for refurbishment. After Pavlo is done fixing and adding polishing touches to a car, it’s ready to be re-sold in Ukraine. Pavlo has been in this business for 2 years. His income was about 15,000 Grivnas before the financial crisis hit Ukraine very hard.

Pavlo is seeking a 5,000 Grivna loan to fix a car for further re-sale. He is happy to have followed his brother’s advice to start this business. Pavlo believes he can apply his technical skills and work in the sphere of vehicles which has always been his passion. Pavlo is really good with all his clients. They all recommend him as a competent and skillful technician and are satisfied with the refurbished cars he had sold them.

loans.use: fix a car for re-sale

loans.name: Valle Totora Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Valle Totora es un Banco inicia su cuarto ciclo con 11 socias, las socias viven en la comunidad D. Valle Totora que se encuentra  a 20 minutos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, es un pequeño valle, la mayoría D. las socias se dedican a la agricultura D. hortalizas y verduras.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la agricultura D. verduras, venta D. frutas, verduras, abarrotes y comida. Sus ventas los realizan en el mercado D. abastos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, y en sus domicilios.
Es el caso D. Agustina que se dedica a la agricultura D. verduras en sus terrenos y luego lo comercializa en la ciudad D. Ayacucho.
Por otro lado Zenaida se dedica a la crianza D. cuy, tiene galpones, sus ventas los realiza en los recreos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 600 soles y 900 soles, haciendo un total D. 5,250 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.
Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra semilla, abono, remedios, pago D. peón, azúcar, arroz y para el pago D. alquiler D. chacras.
Los sueños D. las socias son comprar mas terrenos, construir su casa con material noble y hacer crecer su negocio.
texts.en:
The Valle Totora Community Bank is starting its fourth loan cycle with 11 members. The members live in the community of Valle Totora, which is located 20 minutes away from the city of Ayacucho. It is in a small valley, and the majority of the members work in the agriculture field with different types of vegetables. The members run different businesses such as growing vegetables, and selling fruit, vegetables, groceries and food. They make their sales in the wholesale food market in Ayacucho, and also from their homes. For example, Agustina grows vegetables in her fields, and then sells them in Ayacucho. On the other hand, Zenaida raises guinea pigs (a traditional Peruvian food served on special occasions) in sheds, and makes her sales to restaurants in Ayacucho. The members need different loan amounts, ranging from 300 soles to 900 soles, and making a total of 5,250 soles in loans to the community bank. The loans will be used to pay for seed, fertilizer, agricultural supplements, labor costs, sugar, rice, and to rent farmland. The members dream of buying more farmland, building their houses with better construction materials, and growing their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for seed, fertilizer, agricultural supplements, labor costs, sugar, rice, and to rent farmland

loans.name: Neida Martina

texts.es: DOÑA MARTINA QUE CUENTA CON 35 AÑOS VIVE EN SU PROPIA CASA UBICADA EN LA COMUNIDAD DE AZUZAQUI, JUNTO A SU ESPOSO DE 40 Y SUS 5 HIJOS DE 3-7-15-17 Y 19 AÑOS DE EDAD. LA SRA. T. TRABAJA COMO AGENTE MUNICIPAL DE DICHA COMUNIDAD Y SU ESPOSO EL CO DEUDOR ES EL ENCARGADO DE LA MATERNIDAD DE CHANCHOS EN LA AGROPECUARIA C Y M. NO HAY COMPETENCIA PORQUE AMBOS SON EMPLEADOS FIJOS Y SEGUROS; UNO PUBLICO Y EL OTRO PRIVADO, DONDE PERCIBEN SALARIOS MENSUALES. LA SRA. MARTINA INVIRTIO TODO SU CREDITO EN LA COMPRA DE MATERIALES DE CONSTRUCCION. ESTE SERIA EL QUINTO PRESTAMO DE DOÑA MARTINA Y TODOS LOS ANTERIORES LOS A CANCELADO PUNTUALMENTE. ELLA NO TIENE DEUDA EN NINGUNA OTRA FINANCIERA.
texts.en:
Martina is 35 years old and lives in her own home in the community of Azuzaqui together with her husband, who is 40 years old, and their five children, who are 3,7, 15, 17 and 19 years old. She works as a municipal agent in Azuzaqui, and her husband, the co-debtor, is in charge of raising pigs in the CyM Co-op.
